Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Elastomeric Passive Transmission for Dynamic Adjustment of Mechanical Advantage
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is based on a device which passively adjusts the mechanical advantage of a motor-driven actuator. This device, known as the Elastomeric Passive Transmission (EPT), improves the force and speed of tendon-driven actuation systems with minimal impact to their size, weight, and cost. Approximately 40,000 people per year suffer from major upper limb loss in the United States. The grip strength, grasping speed, and active degrees-of-freedom of even the most advanced prosthetic hands used by these patients pale in comparison to those of a human hand. User studies have shown that 90% of patients with myoelectric prostheses consider their prosthetic hand to be too slow and 79% consider it to be too heavy. By incorporating the EPT into their designs, prosthetic limb manufacturers can increase the force and speed of their devices with reduced cost and weight. In addition to improving the performance of prosthetics, the EPT has the potential to bring performance benefits to grippers and manipulators in the field of robotic automation.

This I-Corps project is leverages advances in additive manufacturing to produce simple, low-cost components to improve the performance of electromechanical systems. Each EPT is a composite consisting of both hard and soft polyurethane sections. The hard polyurethane serves as the core of the EPT ensuring that it does not slip on the motor shaft. This core is surrounded by a ring of soft, stretchable struts which give the system its dynamic spooling radius. The EPTs are 3D-printed in two parts and bonded together during the final curing stage. This leads to a single component transmission system which can passively sense the environment and adjust the output of a motor to improve performance and control. The benefits of EPTs have been demonstrated through integration into a 3D-printed prosthetic hand which demonstrates high speed and high force in an inexpensive and lightweight package.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The EPT is a simple, low-cost transmission designed to improve the performance of robotic actuators. In traditional tendon-driven actuation systems, a designer must decide the optimal radius of the tendon-winding spool. A higher radius will make the actuator faster, but this extra speed is at the expense of the maximum output force. If an actuator is twice as fast it will only be half as strong. The EPT allows a designer to achieve the best of both worlds by dynamically adjusting the mechanical advantage of the system. It does this by using soft materials which deform in response to external forces.  Because we 3D print it out of soft material, it is much more compact than comparable Continuously Variable Transmissions (CVTs).

We incorporated six EPTs into a 3d-printed prosthetic hand to demonstrate their ability to produce high speed and high force in a small form factor. Using proximity sensors embedded in the fingers, we showed that the hand has the speed to catch oncoming objects. Along with this speed each fingertip can exert 32 Newtons (or 7 pounds) of force. An adult human hand has ~45 N per finger. In the future we plan to use our EPTs to provide these performance benefits to robotic systems across a diverse array of markets.

The EPT is a simple, low-cost transmission designed to improve the performance of robotic actuators. In traditional tendon-driven actuation systems, a designer must decide the optimal radius of the tendon-winding spool. A higher radius will make the actuator faster, but this extra speed is at the expense of the maximum output force. If an actuator is twice as fast it will only be half as strong. The EPT allows a designer to achieve the best of both worlds by dynamically adjusting the mechanical advantage of the system. It does this by using soft materials which deform in response to external forces.

We incorporated six EPTs into a 3d-printed prosthetic hand to demonstrate their ability to produce high speed and high force in a small form factor. We showed that the hand has the speed to catch oncoming objects along with the ability to exert up to 32 Newtons (or 7 pounds) of force per finger. In the future we plan to use our EPTs to provide these performance benefits to robotic systems across a diverse array of markets.

Our EPT defaults to high-speed operation until an external force is applied to the actuator. This external force causes in increase in the tendon’s tension which compresses the rubber-like struts of the EPT--decreasing it’s radius and increasing its maximum output output force. We make our EPTs using a 3d-printing process called Digital Light Synthesis - a form of projection stereolithography.

These EPTs allow a small electric motor to behave like a much bigger one. When these motors spool a wire around the EPT, the radius of the spool is large allowing for a fast spooling rate; however, when tension is applied by the wire, the radius of the EPT decreases and allows greater torque. This automatic velocity-force adaptation follows the form of the typical human hand closing motion.

Because these EPTs allowed us to make powered prosthetics that are similar in performance to human hands, and better in many ways than existing powered prosthetics we hypothesized that there would be a need by amputees for our advanced prosthetic enabled by EPTs. We entered into the I Corps program to gain instruction and resources to test this hypothesis.

The use of EPTs have more applications than prosthetics, however, and could allow for more ubiquitous use of robots -- high performance and low cost. Because of this additional hypothetical use of EPTs, we began the I Corps program with a broader net of utility and reached out to other robotics companies.

The final outcome was that we found our EPTs driven prosthetics are too early for the market and provide functions that currently would not be used. Therefore, it is a no-go. We did find that automatically fitting and comfortable sockets for prosthetics would be a viable product, and are now considering designs to enable this technology.
